_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Matheson is committed to the safety of its employees and neighbors and operates the facility as a responsible member of the community.  Matheson encourages personnel to continually identify methods and procedures to reduce the use and risks associated with hazardous chemicals.  This process includes protecting the community, environment, and personnel by implementing technology and procedures designed to reduce the impact of any potential release of toxic chemicals.  This commitment to safety is documented in the policy and compliance manuals for this facility, which are available to all employees.

As part of Matheson's commitment to safe and environmentally friendly operations, monthly meetings are conducted with all employees as well as other more specific operational meetings concerning safety.  Input and comments from plant personnel are also key aspects of Matheson's safety practices: By giving personnel the ability to make suggestions regarding safety and operational practices, the facility can operate efficiently and safely.  Another key element in Matheson's safety practices consists of the regular internal and third party environmental and safety audits.

Regulated Substances

The Matheson facility receives, stores, manufactures, and ships the following regulated chemicals: n-Butane, 1-Butene, Carbon Monoxide, Ethylene, Isobutane, Isopentane, Methane, n-Pentane, Propane, Propylene, and Isobutylene.  These chemicals are regulated at the Program 3 level.

Offsite Release Scenarios

Matheson has conducted an offsite consequence analysis based on the EPA's RMP Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidelines, and used the EPA's RMP*Comp Version 1.07 to estimate the distance traveled to a toxic endpoint defined by the EPA.  This data was then used to estimate the potential impact caused by a release from each of the regulated substances.

Worst-Case Release Scenarios

Using the Risk Management Program Guidan

ce for Offsite Consequence Analysis (March 2009), the worst case release for flammable substances is as such: The total quantity of the flammable substance is assumed to form a vapor cloud.  The entire contents of the cloud are assumed to be within the flammability limits, and the cloud is assumed to explode.

It also states that for the worst case analysis 10% of the flammable vapor in the cloud is assumed to participate in the explosion (i.e. the yield factor is 0.10).  The worst case scenario requires that the facility estimate the consequence distance to an overpressure level of 1 pound per square inch (psi) from the explosion vapor cloud.

Alternative Release Scenario

Based on a review of facility operating history and accident history, the Process Hazard Analysis, and knowledge of industry incidents, the alternative release scenario was chosen as a likely scenario as the facility frequently transfers hazardous materials to and from the process tanks during deliveries or truck loadings.  Specifically, the alternate case scenario was defined to be a transfer hose malfunction associated with Tank 020 (Propane).

General Accidental Release Prevention Programs and Prevention Steps

As part of the implementation of the PSM/RMP, elements of the prevention programs have been developed to manage process safety issues associated with the facility.  Each of the program elements have been developed according to OSHA and EPA regulations in order to ensure safe operating practices and conditions at the Matheson facility.

Prevention 3 Elements:

Process Safety Information - information regarding the hazards each chemical, process descriptions, and equipment properties.

Process Hazards Analysis - a detailed review of the process and recommendations to improve the safety of the system.

Operating Procedures - procedures designed to comply with regulations and provide safe practices for the system.

Training - procedures and logs for personnel training on the covered process

es.

Mechanical Integrity - manufacturer recommended maintenance procedures, schedules, and documentation.

Management of Change - documentation and tracking of changes that effect the process involving the regulated chemicals.

Pre-Startup Safety Review - prior to the startup of a new regulated process or major changes to the existing process, a review will be conducted as required by the PSM/RMP regulations.

Compliance Audits - documentation of tri-annual audits of the covered process.

Incident Investigation - documentation and investigation procedures for determining and mitigating releases.

Employee Participation - documentation and statement of Matheson's commitment to providing a safe and open work place.

Hot Work Permit - procedures for documenting and safely performing work on or near process equipment during normal operations.

Contractors - policy for contractors and outside vendors that work on or near the regulated process.

These elements are continually updated and reviewed through the Management System at Matheson.  The Management System includes planning, organizing, implementing, and controlling different aspects of the plan.

Five Year Accident History

There has been one RMP applicable accident of a regulated chemical at the facility in the past five years.  The chemical involved in the incident as propane.  There was a fire onsite on February 8, 2005 that was caused by a leak between a pump (p-016) associated with Tank 007 and a hand valve (HV-020).  The East Greenville Fire Department was dispatched to the site at 8:21 AM and arrived onsite at 8:30 AM.  The fuel (propane) supply valve was closed at 8:49 AM and the situation was under control at 9:12 AM.  The facility performed and incident investigation and determined that the leak persisted for not more than 20 minutes before the supply valve was closed.  After the supply valve was closed a leak at a lower pressure persisted for approximately 28 more minutes.  

The total calculated amount

of propane lost during the onsite fire was 9,140 pounds.  There were no injuries to facility personnel however there was some surrounding equipment damage due to the fire. The issues have since been resolved and as a result of this incident, the storage tanks onsite have been equipped with al fusible link that shuts the liquid supply valve coming out of the tank to stop the fuel to the fire.  The fusible links are rated for 212 psi, the lead melts and the lever releases shutting the valve.

Emergency Action Plan
Matheson has implemented a corporate Emergency Action Plan, which includes emergency and evacuation procedures, safety and health considerations, and notification procedures.

Planned Changes

Changes determined by the Process Hazard Analysis and consideration made during the development of this plan will be conducted in a timely manner.

Updates

The PSM/RMP will be updated at least every five years and is due to be updated on the five year anniversary of the PHA study (May 2014).  The PSM/RMP will also be updated within six months in the event of a change which requires a new Process Hazard Analysis.
